Name: latin
Notes:
Courses in Latin are offered through the Department of Classical Studies.
Students should consult with the departmental undergraduate
advisor
for the latest information on course offerings. Some courses are
offered
in rotation.
Senior standing in Latin is normally defined as successful
completion
of LAT 201 and LAT 202;
exceptional students may also be admitted to 300- or 400-level courses
with instructor's permission.

Courses.Name: Introductory Latin 1
Courses.Desc: A course designed for students beginning the study of Latin or who have not yet reached the level expected in LAT 201/202. Although the teaching approach emphasizes exposure to simple texts as soon as possible, students desiring minimal competence in reading should go on to do LAT 102.

Courses.Name: Introductory Latin 2
Courses.Desc: Continuation of LAT 101. Most of the rules of Latin grammar will be covered by the end of the year, and students should have a minimal competence in reading prose texts; but for the remaining grammar and further practice students should go on to do LAT 201.

Courses.Name: Intermediate Latin
Courses.Desc: The course will complete the study of Latin grammar and move on to unadapted readings in Latin authors, particularly Caesar.

Courses.Name: Selections from Latin Authors
Courses.Desc: A course designed to follow LAT 201, including both literature and grammar review. Authors normally read are Vergil and Ovid.

Courses.Name: Intermediate Latin: Translation and Interpretation
Courses.Desc: A selection of unadapted material from one or two authors or an investigation of selected themes or topics at the intermediate level. Authors such as Livy, Caesar, Cicero, Catullus, Vergil, or Ovid may be studied. Topics may include desire, death, war, identity, or a specific genre such as tragedy, to name but a few.
Courses.Notes: [Note: Permission to register is by consent of the undergraduate advisor. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

Courses.Name: Advanced Readings in Latin: Prose
Courses.Desc: A selection of material from one author or several authors within the field of Latin prose. Topics and selections may include oratory and rhetoric, history, philosophy, Cicero, Quintilian, Caesar, Livy, and Apuleius.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

Courses.Name: Advanced Readings in Latin: Poetry
Courses.Desc: A selection of material from one author or several authors within the field of Latin poetry. Topics and selections may include comedy, lyric poetry, elegy, epic, Plautus, Terence, Catullus, Ovid, and Vergil.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

Courses.Name: Advanced Studies in Latin: Selected Topics
Courses.Desc: An investigation of selected themes, topics, time periods, or genres in Latin.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

Courses.Name: Latin Composition, Grammar, and Reading
Courses.Desc: Composition, translation, and grammar with intensive analysis of selected passages.

Courses.Name: Medieval Latin
Courses.Desc: Survey of Medieval Latin poetry and prose.

Courses.Name: Latin Epigraphy
Courses.Desc: The course introduces and investigates Latin inscriptions as evidence for the Latin language and Roman political, religious, legal, social, and economic history.

Courses.Name: Latin Palaeography
Courses.Desc: A practical overview of the various styles of Latin handwriting from the late Roman Empire to the writing styles of the Renaissance humanists which introduces students to the study of original documents and manuscripts.

Courses.Name: Senior Latin Composition, Grammar, and Reading
Courses.Desc: Advanced composition, translation, and grammar with intensive analysis of selected passages.

Courses.Name: Senior Studies in Latin: Selected Topics
Courses.Desc: A selection of material from one author or several authors or an investigation of selected themes, topics, or genres at the senior level. Topics and authors may include philosophy, letter writing, history, elegy, satire, Seneca, Pliny the Younger, Tacitus, Propertius, Petronius, and Juvenal.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: At least 0.5 unit in a 300-level LAT course

Courses.Name: Senior Studies in Latin: Independent Study
Courses.Desc: Under special circumstances and with the approval of the department, a student or small group of students may arrange to pursue individualized readings under the supervision of a faculty member.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of ten times.]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: At least 0.5 unit in a 300-level LAT course
